;Wang Dongling has a notebook with "dirty material". The notebook is filled with comments from netizens who "spite" him, such as "Wang Dongling is a braggart" and "Wang Dongling has gone crazy..." Wang Dongling opened the notebook, which contained both serious critical articles and vulgar abuse. "When a compilation of information about me is printed in the future, all of this can be printed." Wang Dongling said with a smile.

;

;;

;

;In November 2016, Wang Dongling's calligraphy art solo exhibition opened at the Taimiao Art Museum in Beijing, and he was swiping at the scene. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;Wang Dongling is a calligrapher, but he is also happy to be called a calligrapher. modern artist. Rather than being praised by his peers, the "chaotic books" he created gained more from the incomprehension of ordinary audiences. Wang Dongling's "chaotic calligraphy" is not the first to be criticized for modern calligraphy, and it will certainly not be the last. In recent years, netizens have criticized Zeng Xiang's "Roaring Book", Zhang Qiang's "Blind Book" and Shao Yan's "Shooting Book"... As the name suggests, when creating "Roaring Book", Zeng Xiang was drunk. He seemed to be mad, roaring and yelling; when Zhang Qiang wrote, he didn't look at the brush and the writing object, and applied it by hand; Shao Yan filled the ink with a needle and sprayed the words on the rice paper, which can be said to follow the shape of the object... Popular opinion Not understanding these various new "calligraphy", some people simply call them "ugly calligraphy". In the newly released movie "The Story of Yong'an Town", the director who is good at ridicule pokes fun at the film industry, but also satirizes the "Master of Shouting Books".

;

;Compared with them, Wang Dongling still looks like traditional calligraphy at least in the "movements" of his creation - but people still can't see clearly what he wrote in his "random calligraphy". When I open a piece of Wang Dongling's "chaos calligraphy" work, I can see intersecting lines, like dead branches on the ground, and like swords fighting in chaos, but not a single clear and independent Chinese character can be seen.

;

;;

;

;Wang Dongling's "Li Bai Poetic" calligraphy installation was exhibited at the China Academy of Art Museum's "Calligraphy·Not Calligraphy - 2019 International Modern Calligraphy Art Festival". ;(Visual China/Picture);

;

;At a social inscription scene, Wang Dongling asked the organizer with a sly smile, "Do you want me to Should you write more messily or be more disciplined?" The words to be inscribed were "Art for a better life". The organizer nodded Weiwei and said, "Be more disciplined, be more disciplined." Wang Dongling picked up the brush and thought for a moment. Several big words had already fallen on it. on paper. Looking carefully, the strokes of these characters are indeed much more "regular", with adhesion but little overlap. "My characters are not very intertwined, but there is still some expressiveness in them." Wang Dongling told Southern Weekend the reporter said.

;

;Like Wang Dongling, Zeng Xiang, Shao Yan and Zhang Qiang can also write very "proper" characters. When the public laughs at them, few people ask why they give up "proper" writing. Calligraphy, doing these things that look like performance art?

;

;;

;

;Not all of Wang Dongling's works are in the form of "chaotic calligraphy". The picture shows his works on display at the Zhejiang Art Museum in 2021. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;"Everyone has the desire to criticize and explain. I am now a target to let people have this desire. It looks good to me," Wang Dongling said. Nearly eighty years old, he seems to be in a good mood. He said that when he was young, he could not hear scolding, which would make him feel uncomfortable, but now he has become "early", and he would sometimes laugh out loud when looking through the notebook with "dirty information".

;

;Breaking the "Word Barrier"

;

;Wang Dongling has a thin figure, with dry white hair and messy hair. Sometimes she speaks in a breathless voice, and you have to get closer to hear it clearly. It was startling. If his voice is compared to a calligraphy work, then his layout is what Deng Shiru said: "It can be sparse but airtight."

;

;;

;

;Wang Dongling once presented Chinese cultural classics in the form of "chaotic scripts" and "wall scripts". The picture shows the large-scale mirror wall book "I Ching" he exhibited in 2016. It is written on a stainless steel plate with white paint and is 32 meters long and 3.5 meters high. ;(Visual China/Picture);

;

;The first impression given by "Chaoshu" is its white cloth and unique composition. "Zhangfa" and "Bubai" are calligraphy terms, which refer to the arrangement, layout and mutual response between words and lines during the entire writing process. In traditional calligraphy works, the line spacing is roughly clear, and the strokes cannot cross between words. Even the continuous grass of the late Ming Dynasty will still generally abide by such rules. "Look at Xu Wei's "Ying Zhi Ying Sword", there are a few places where the strokes touch and cross, but it is not obvious." Wang Dongling zoomed in on Xu Wei's work on her mobile phone and kept zooming in until the complete picture could no longer be seen. Glyphs and dancing lines fill the entire phone screen.

;

;When he was a child, Wang Dongling observed an old tree in front of his teacher’s house, and the zigzag lines were imprinted in his memory. Later, he also looked at the trees in the American wilderness and found that the lines created by the vitality of the trees were different, but intersected harmoniously.

;

;Every winter, he goes to see the dead lotuses on the West Lake. He has more than 20,000 photos of dead lotuses on his computer. Look at the dead lotus stems, all scattered and scattered, seemingly chaotic, but there is an underlying order in the chaos. When the ideographic nature of Chinese characters is completely covered up - like the enlarged Xu Wei that makes it difficult to see what character it is, then only the lines of the Chinese characters are left in front of the viewer's eyes.

;

;In the history of calligraphy, the "overlapping" of characters can be traced back to Yan Zhenqing's "Seat Struggle", but that may be unconscious. When it came to Xu Wei, "I think his calligraphy was intended to break the line spacing," Wang Dongling said. Later, Zheng Banqiao's calligraphy was called "paving the streets with random stones." "In fact, they all wanted to break the calligraphy and line spacing." "

;

;"Chaoshu" is to push this "break" to the extreme. If you look at Wang Dongling's random writing process, every word he writes is actually in accordance with cursive writing (cursive, a calligraphy term, refers to the cursive writing rules of Chinese characters. The cursive writing of each character is roughly fixed and conventional). "It's nothing more than an overlap."

;

;When words overlap and strokes intertwine, the viewer cannot clearly see what is written. Therefore, the "word barrier" for Chinese people to read calligraphy is broken, and they can concentrate on feeling the lines. flow.

;

;;

;

;In 2021, the 60-year exhibition of Wang Dongling's calligraphy art was held at Zhejiang Art Museum. The picture shows an audience staying in front of Wang Dongling's works. ;(Visual China/Picture);

;

;For Chinese people, when they look at a piece of calligraphy, they first of course want to understand what it says. , in Wang Dongling's opinion, is a "writing barrier", which keeps many ordinary people away from the deeper beauty of calligraphy. Just like someone listens to his mother tongue and understands the meaning, but unconsciously ignores the beauty of the pronunciation. Only people who do not understand the language at all will notice the high and low pitch values ​​and the gentleness of the timbre when listening. .

;

;"Calligraphy has developed over thousands of years. Traditional calligraphy has been very perfect and mature. It is difficult for you to break through at all." Wang Dongling said that calligraphy has two attributes, one is cultural attribute, and the other is cultural attribute. It is Chinese characters written by Chinese people, so we naturally want to understand it, "There is nothing wrong with this", but another attribute of calligraphy is its artistic attribute. If you admit that it is an art, then it must Have personality and express the creator.”

;

;“Chaotic script is the extension of ancient cursive script.” This is Wang Dongling’s own understanding of chaotic script. He puts his creation into the track of the ancients, “Of course my heart is not as wild as Xu Wei’s. , but you must have passion to write cursive."

;

; Can people who understand music learn calligraphy faster?

;

;Walking into Wang Dongling’s studio, the floor is covered with all kinds of manuscript papers, rice paper, and albums. It can be said to be a “street full of paper.” This studio has received many foreigners who admired Chinese calligraphy. "Professor Wang Dongling gave me my first calligraphy lesson." In 2015, Apple CEO Tim Cook said on Weibo. At that time, Cook visited Wang Dongling's studio, and Wang Dongling taught him to use Apple pencil to write the word "goodbye" with calligraphy strokes on the iPad. Prior to this, he was invited to Apple headquarters in California to provide professional calligraphy advice on the iPad’s writing capabilities.

;

;For Apple, this Weibo undoubtedly has a strong marketing temperament, but Wang Dongling does not reject invitations from other cultures.

;

;In March 1989, Wang Dongling went to give lectures at the University of Minnesota in the United States. What he brought with him was a large pen and the "Longzang Temple Stele" which he copied repeatedly. Wang Dongling still remembers the winter in Minnesota, when there was heavy snow outside the window, and his car was stuck deep in the snow, like an ink mark in the snow.

;

;Wang Dongling’s English is very poor. In his own words, when he first arrived in the United States, he didn’t know all 26 letters. So far, I may only recognize 200 words. But he is very willing to exchange calligraphy with foreigners. In 1981, Wang Dongling received a master's degree in calligraphy from Zhejiang Academy of Fine Arts (now China Academy of Art) and stayed at the school to teach. At that time, Zhejiang Academy of Fine Arts was the only school in the country that majored in calligraphy, so the Ministry of Culture sent all international students studying calligraphy to Zhejiang Academy of Fine Arts. From then on, Wang Dongling took on the task of teaching calligraphy to international students.

;

;Even now, many people still feel that it is impossible to teach Westerners to learn calligraphy. They do not understand ancient Chinese, and learning Chinese characters does not happen overnight. But Wang Dongling's teaching practice told him that this does not seem to be the case. "They often make mistakes in stroke order and structure, and even write wrong words. But this is not a problem." In Wang Dongling's view, foreigners have overcome the "writing barrier" from the beginning.

;

;British art historian Gombrich once concluded that the role of calligraphy in Chinese culture corresponds well with music in European culture. Wang Dongling's experience tells him that students who have previous musical accomplishments will learn faster. "The form of cursive calligraphy art is a division of space by overflowing tension and irregular lines. This kind of space displayed after black and white treatment is full of changes in virtual reality and rhythm, and it is a musical space." Wang Dongling said .

;

;The Internet celebrity "Teacher Andy" of Bilibili, who is now over seventy years old, has been working tirelessly to popularize Western classical music to the public on the Chinese Internet in recent years. His full name is Andreas Stier. German, he is a piano professor at the Hamburg State University of Music. He was once a student of Wang Dongling. Wang Dongling still remembers that in the 1980s, he took Andy Shi and several other international students to the home of Mr. Lu Yanshao. Mr. Lu Yanshao read the works of several foreign students in turn and saw the "Silence" in the "Taishan Diamond Sutra" written by Andy Shi. "Chinese people have not been able to write at this level for a long time."

;In 1990, Wang Dongling was in the United States, watching various contemporary art and contemporary dances. Once, he watched an artistic performance by American middle school students. There were solo dances and group dances of three people. The children were twisting their bodies unscrupulously. "Their body language made me feel that no matter how innovative Chinese calligraphy is, it should be allowed," he said. "Wang Dongling said that graffiti, like dancing, is one of human instincts. "The writing of Chinese characters has a strong graffiti nature. Calligraphy is a spiritual artistic product that combines human instincts with Chinese characters." And in Kuangcao. In "Kang Cao", human instincts are released as much as possible. "Kang Cao is greatly weakened from the constraints of ranks, providing a free world for the author to express space. In Kuang Cao, the writing, rhythm and rhythm of calligraphy are brought into full play." ”

;Traditional calligraphy, Jianghu style, modern calligraphy

;

;Although Wang Dongling looks thin, in the face of the physically demanding calligraphy, he can write the large-scale "Thousand-Character Essay" 》. It took four hours to write a random piece of "The Thousand Character Essay". In Wang Dongling's own words, it was indeed improvised writing, but it was not a "disordered accident, but a kind of muscle memory after years of training." And when writing, you should always pay attention to the connection between words and the overall layout.

;

;Qi Gong once said, "Layout is very difficult." Layout has also become one of the criteria that distinguishes professional calligraphers from calligraphy enthusiasts generally known as "Jianghu style".

;

;In Wang Dongling's opinion, the current people who study calligraphy can be roughly divided into three types of people. One type is those who follow the traditional path, conscientiously write posts and monuments, and write "good-looking" characters according to traditional standards. This type of people is the cornerstone of calligraphy. The second category is the "jianghu style". "With the participation of all people now, there must be some people who are not good at basic skills but are eager for quick success and quick success. They attract people's attention but have no level. These people can be called 'jianghu style'."< /p>;

;There are also some people who want calligraphy to become a breakthrough modern art. Not only are there people like Wang Dongling who are making breakthroughs within calligraphy, but there are also people who are combining calligraphy with contemporary art such as installation, performance, and video. Some of the "ugly books" considered by the public come from the Jianghu style, and a large number of them come from this group. Wang Dongling also makes no secret that he belongs to the third category. Although his daily training is the same as that of traditional calligraphers, he also has to write calligraphy every day. "In the final analysis, modern calligraphy is to express people's emotions. I am a firm supporter of modern calligraphy and Promoter".

;

;Few people know that the establishment of the first calligraphy major in China actually came from the influence of modern calligraphy. After World War II, Japan regarded calligraphy as an art, engaged in modern calligraphy and avant-garde calligraphy, and attached great importance to the popularization of calligraphy education. In the early 1960s, Pan Tianshou went to Japan to study calligraphy and was deeply moved. He returned to Hangzhou and founded China's first calligraphy and seal cutting major at the Zhejiang Academy of Fine Arts with Sha Menghai, Lu Weizhao and others.

;

;In 1979, Zhejiang Academy of Fine Arts was commissioned by the Ministry of Culture to recruit the first master's degree students in calligraphy in the country. Wang Dongling became a student of Sha Menghai, Lu Weizhao and other gentlemen, and was one of the first five masters of calligraphy in New China. In the autumn of 1980, Wang Dongling accompanied Mr. Sha Menghai to Beijing to see the original stone drum exhibition at the Palace Museum. I have read Han Yu's "Song of the Stone Drum", seen the original rubbings of "The Inscriptions on the Stone Drum", and read Wu Changshuo's "The Inscription on the Stone Drum", but when I saw the original copy of the Stone Drum, "Even if I don't look at the specific words, the kind of text that the Stone Drum carries The atmosphere of ancient times makes people deeply moved. This experience is the same as looking at the statue in front of Huo Qubing's tomb, which is very wonderful." In Wang Dongling's own memories, this trip to Beijing brought a great shock to his artistic concept. "I feel that the highest state of calligraphy is far from the stability and exquisiteness of pointillism. What is more important is that lines can carry abundant vitality and inexhaustible vitality."

;

;In the 1990s, Wang Dongling After returning to the United States, he began to devote himself to promoting and practicing modern calligraphy. Since then, he has been subjected to pressure and ridicule from all walks of life. At first, there were doubts from the professional calligraphy community. In recent years, the situation has reversed. The professional calligraphy community has turned to a positive evaluation of him, but the public in the Internet age has made an even harsher voice.

;

;Wang Dongling has some intuitive self-explanations to explain the creation process of chaos books to the public, such as Huai Su watching the peaks of summer with many strange clouds, Zhang Xu watching Gongsun Auntie dancing with a sword, Huang Tingjian watching the boatmen rowing, all enlightened He developed new calligraphy skills, and connected his random calligraphy with the residual lotus. When asked if this was an afterthought, he smiled and said, "the two grew out of each other."

;

;Like Zeng Xiang, the "master of shouting", he likes to write big characters. When he writes, there are many onlookers - but Wang Dongling basically doesn't shout. When writing calligraphy, people are watching and cheering. This is also a tradition. When Zhang Xu writes cursive script, people often watch him. Jin Shengtan listed thirty-three joyful things in life, one of which is "How wonderful it is to watch people write big books in a nest!" He also hopes that people can enjoy calligraphy with the mood of "It is wonderful".

;Wang Dongling supports the innovation of calligraphy as a modern art, but he seems quite hesitant about one question. A reporter from Southern Weekend asked him: "Will the innovations of some young people with weak basic skills be successful?" Will it be superficial? But if young people follow the tradition and practice to the state of "old people and books" as the ancients said, and then make innovations and breakthroughs, have they missed the best time in their lives? Is there any hidden meaning in this? Contradiction?" For a person who is still enthusiastic about creation when he is nearly eighty years old, this may not be a problem. Wang Dongling paused for a long time and replied: "Creation must have good basic skills. People with good basic skills should promote them. Create more."
